post: Methemoglobin is a form of hemoglobin that contains ferric [Fe3+] iron and has a decreased ability to bind oxygen. Signs and symptoms of methemoglobinemia (methemoglobin level above 1%) include shortness of breath, cyanosis, mental status changes (~50%), headache, fatigue, exercise intolerance, dizziness and loss of hairlines. I think the “last words of Christ on Cross” are not in favor of this clinical picture. Therefore it would seem there was not present the iron III (= Fe3+ in methemoglobin) and thus A.v.d.H.
